newsitem.title: USA: Congressman says U.S. aiding China arms buildup.
newsitem.headline: Congressman says U.S. aiding China arms buildup.

text.p: A House Republican committee chairman said Thursday that China was exploiting Clinton administration-approved U.S. arms sales to modernize its military as fast as possible.

"I am very concerned that we're selling our edge in military technology to a nation that may well be our adversary some day," Rep. Floyd Spence, chairman of the House National Security Committee, said in a statement.
Spence said he was concerned that the Clinton administration had put the commercial arms sales interests above U.S. national security.
"We must not compromise our national security by giving the Chinese the means to increase their military effectiveness," the South Carolina Republican said.
Spence made the comments in releasing four reports on U.S. trade with China and while Secretary of State Warren Christopher was in Beijing trying to improve U.S.-Sino relations.

"When you add it all up, it is clear that China's military is exploiting the existing international technology transfer rules -- even breaking specific agreements and U.S. laws -- to modernize as fast as it can," Spence said.
"I am particularly concerned about the recent expansion of sensitive military technology exports to China, he said.

He said that despite strong warnings from U.S. military and intelligence officials, the Clinton administration allowed a sale of advanced machine tools to China in 1994 that China diverted from civilian use to use in a factory that makes combat planes, ballistic missiles and cruise missiles.

Spence released a congressional General Accounting Office report saying McDonnell Douglas had used the parts-shaping machines to make U.S. military planes and missiles but sold them to China for its manufacture of civilian airliners.
But some of the machines were instead shipped to China's Nanchang Aircraft Co, which produces military planes and missiles as well as civilian products, the GAO report said.
It said that diversion was prohibited by conditions the U.S. government imposed on the sale and the machines were moved before they could be misused.

A second GAO report said AT&T sold high-speed picture and sound telecommunications equipment, used for tele-conferencing and telemedicine, to HuaMei, a civilian joint venture that has a partner controlled by China's military.

The report said the U.S. exporter is responsible for assuring the equipment is sold to a civilian company. But it said the equipment could be used for military command and control and it is hard for the U.S. exporter to know whether HuaMei is a civilian company despite the military involvement.
